results.title: Arrows against the wind
results.creator_credit: A Land Beyond Production, SBS-TV and Tracey Groome
results.brief_description: Describes the culture and traditional way of life of the indigenous peoples of West Papua (Irian Jaya), and the social, political and environmental upheaval they have endured since the beginning of Indonesian rule in 1963. Outlines their continuing struggle for social justice and self-determination.
results.creator_credit_for_label: A Land Beyond Production, SBS-TV and Tracey Groome

results.title: Arrow to the sun
results.brief_description: A film which uses animation to tell the tale of the Acoma Pueblo Indians about a boy’s search for his father, entailing his voyage on an arrow to the Sun, trials he undergoes in the sky village until he is recognised by his father, the lord of the sun, and his return to earth to spread the sun’s warm delights. Based on the Caldecott Medal winning book by Gerald McDermott.

results.title: Arrivederci Roma
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Richard Zatorski and Geoffrey Wright
results.brief_description: A new Australian comes to grips with his first physical education swimming lesson and makes some friends along the way to the deep end. Set in the City Baths, Melbourne. Stars Bill Banks, Rob Forza, Claudio Avilla and John White.

results.title: Arrivederci Roma
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Richard Zatorski and Geoffrey Wright
results.brief_description: Marinelli (Robert Forza) is a new immigrant to Australia who experiences difficulties when confronted with the harshness of the Anglo-saxon culture during a swimming lesson. With an inability to speak English, Marinelli is plunged into the deep end of the pool and cultural survival. Directed by Geoffrey Wright known mostly for ‘Romper Stomper’ and ‘Metal Skin’. Filmed at the City Baths, Melbourne.

results.title: Array back when
results.brief_description: Breakfast to the Egyptian slaves, was a painstaking occupation. They could rarely get to work on time because the cook could not supply the required number of eggs to them. He had no system of organizing eggs into manageable number groups. A yo-yo salesman shows how grouping things into sets of twelve makes handling and counting more efficient. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Around the World with Dot
results.brief_description: In “Around the World with Dot” there are carefully interwoven elements of history, geography, bushlore, conservation and social studies with the animated action so that children of all ages will be educated while being entertained. Rated: G

results.title: Around the world under the sea
results.brief_description: Action adventure film about a group of scientists led by Dr Doug Standish (Lloyd Bridges) who set out in a submarine to plant sensors along the world’s ocean floors as an early warning earthquake alert following worldwide increased seismic activity. Cast includes Brian Kelly, David McCallum, Keenan Wynn, Marshall Thompson, Gary Merrill, Shirley Eaton.

results.title: Around the clock
results.creator_credit: Department of Postmaster-General, Kestrel Films & Video (Australia), John Richardson and David Morgan
results.brief_description: There are approximately 5,500 official and unofficial post offices under the auspices of Australia Post. The film shows various aspects of the work done by Australia Post, moving mail by land, air, and sea. No credits available.

results.title: Around the boree log (1925)
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and Phil K Walsh
results.brief_description: Shot in the district around Goulburn, NSW near Wollondilly river, this historical silent film warmly depicts bush life in Australia in the 1870’s of early Catholic settlers as described in the poem of the title. The priest and poet, Father John O’Brien (aka Father Patrick Hartigan), appears in the film reading prose as the story begins. The humorous tale recounts his childhood experiences of childhood and education in the bush. Wonderful images include the ‘old shaky slab hut school’ and the bush salesman where the mother buys the children each a hat, humourously described…”six ugly extinguishers that fitted us too soon - six ugly upturned canisters, each one a thing of gloom”. The film was not without controversy. When the film was first screened, reactions were mixed because of its obvious Catholic bias; some distributors even refusing to screen it, seeing it as Catholic propaganda. Today, as then, the film is still a charming recollection of earlier days. With music only, no intertitles.
